results.title: Closer
results.material_description: video, software, sensor pads and vinyl interactive pillars
results.brief_description:
A commission of the Australian Centre of the Moving Image, ‘Closer’ is an interactive dance installation created and produced by renowned contemporary dance company Chunky Move.

A constantly changing audiovisual environment with a single large projection of a solo dancer, Closer plays with the relationship between the audience and the interactive structures created by artists Gideon Obarzanek (Choreography), Peter Hennessey (Interactive and Visual Design), and Darrin Verhagin (Audio Landscape).

Closer combines real time video processing with sensor pads that respond to audience members using their bodies to modify the moves of the on-screen dancer.

The choreography is endlessly modified by the actions of the audience, and the audience’s actions are in turn shaped and defined by the installation, which calls upon them to touch, throw or press their bodies against the upholstered, torso-size sensor pads mounted on the walls in the installation space.

Closer redefines the installation space as a choreographic instrument, which is played by its audience to create new works every time. The work can also be described as an investigative tool, allowing the audience to explore, in more a more detail, the structure and topography of the movement and the body of the dancer. The work literally brings the audience closer to the work in every sense -closer to its creation, closer to the subtle details of its movement and closer to the body of its dancer.

As the audience engages with the work, they become increasingly aware of the reflective relationship they share with the dancer. Their interaction, via large physical actions or movements, is very different from the usual ‘mouse and keyboard’ interface that commonly defines multimedia installations. As they activate the large wall pads, their bodies are pushed into a kind of physicality that is especially unusual in a traditional gallery context. They literally impact on the work.

The choreography in Closer is itself based on impacts. A lone dancer bounces her body against a wall and, as the audience’s input increases, this gentle rebounding is transformed into something far more intense and extraordinary.

Closer, the audience’s experience of dance, usually felt from the passive distance of theatre seats, is active and intimate. The minute complexities of the body - the ripple and flex of skin and muscles, hair, pores and subtle expression - form part of the choreographic palette of Closer. This is micro-choreography. This is Closer.

results.title: Evonne Goolagong Cawley crowns Ash Barty Australian Open champion
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @AusOpen Twitter post
results.brief_description: Ngarigo woman and world number one in women’s singles tennis, Ash Barty, accepts the Daphne Akhurst Memorial Cup after a two-set victory in her Australian Open finals match against Danielle Collins. The trophy was bestowed on her by former world number one, Wiradjuri tennis legend Evonne Goolagong Cawley, who was crowned women’s singles champion at the Australian Open four years running, from 1974-77.
results.title_for_label: Evonne Goolagong Cawley crowns champion Ash Barty at the Australian Open
results.description: Ngarigo woman and women’s tennis world number one Ash Barty accepts the Daphne Akhurst Memorial Cup after a two-set victory in the Australian Open final against Danielle Collins. The trophy was bestowed on her by former world number one, Wiradjuri tennis legend Evonne Goolagong Cawley, who was crowned women’s singles champion at the Australian Open four years running, from 1974-77.

results.title: KKND: Krush Kill 'N Destroy for DOS
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: In the far future of KKND: Krush Kill ‘N Destroy, a nuclear war has destroyed the Earth’s surface. The humans that were left split into two factions: The Survivors are the descendants of humans who managed to burrow under the Earth’s crust before the surface’s annihilation, taking with them what they could salvage. They survived underground for sixty years but dwindling resources has forced them to resurface. They were met by the Mutes, humans who lived through the nuclear destruction, mutated and dominated the Earth. An armed conflict between the two groups is inevitable. The game has you choosing either of these factions. As a classic real-time strategy, the focus on this game is gathering oil, building up and upgrading your base, training units and completing your objectives. Objectives can range from simply destroying an enemy presence to gathering a set amount of materials while fending off enemy attacks.

Objectives can range from simply destroying an enemy presence to gathering a set amount of materials while fending off enemy attacks.

Objectives can range from simply destroying an enemy presence to gathering a set amount of materials while fending off enemy attacks.

results.title: Flight of the Amazon Queen for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert, manual, registration card and installation guide in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Science supervillains are popular across genres, and evil Dr Ironstein from Flight of the Amazon Queen is just such a nefarious mastermind. He has a secret underground bunker with a high-tech lab where he has developed the dino-ray to create an army of dinosaur women with which he plans to rule the world.

constellations_primary.name: Doctors of Evil
constellations_primary.description: Everyone loves villains. They get all the best lines and if they are mad scientists, they get all the best toys too. Evil Dr Ironstein from Flight of the Amazon Queen is just such a nefarious mastermind - one member of long lineage of science supervillains.

constellations_primary.name: Gender bending larrikins
constellations_primary.description: Australia has a long history with gender creativity and drag culture, both on screen and on stage.

results.title_for_label: Flight of the Amazon Queen for PC
results.description:
When Joe King arrives at a Buenos Aires hotel to fly a movie star to a photo shoot, he’s ambushed by rivals who steal his clothes to detain him. To escape, Joe disguises himself as a showgirl and sets off to save the star and stop a mad scientist taking over the world.

Featuring a larrikin hero, Amazonian tribes and booby-trapped temples, you can see the influence of Indiana Jones on Flight of the Amazon Queen. Likewise, it features some outdated references and terminology, but John Passfield and Steven Stamatiadis’ game is emblematic of the popular 1990s point-and-click adventure genre, which often incorporated cinematic storytelling elements.

It’s inspired by games like LucasArts’ Monkey Island series (1990), which use on-screen directions like ‘use’, ‘open’, ‘talk to’ and ‘pick up’ to propel the gameplay. In another daring escape – this time down a laundry chute – Joe ‘picks up’ two sheets and ‘uses’ them to create a rope, just one of the many puzzles players solve.

The game has since been ported to smartphones, with the addition of improved graphics, full voice acting, multi-language support and a play through of the interactive interview mini-game with audio commentary by John Passfield, one of the game’s designers.
description_for_label:
When Joe King arrives at a Buenos Aires hotel to fly a movie star to a photo shoot, he’s ambushed by rivals who steal his clothes to detain him. To escape, Joe disguises himself as a showgirl and sets off to save the star and stop a mad scientist taking over the world.

Featuring a larrikin hero, Amazonian tribes and booby-trapped temples, you can see the influence of Indiana Jones on Flight of the Amazon Queen. Likewise, it features some outdated references and terminology, but John Passfield and Steven Stamatiadis’ game is emblematic of the popular 1990s point-and-click adventure genre, which often incorporated cinematic storytelling elements.

It’s inspired by games like LucasArts’ Monkey Island series (1990), which use on-screen directions like ‘use’, ‘open’, ‘talk to’ and ‘pick up’ to propel the gameplay. In another daring escape – this time down a laundry chute – Joe ‘picks up’ two sheets and ‘uses’ them to create a rope, just one of the many puzzles players solve.

The game has since been ported to smartphones, with the addition of improved graphics, full voice acting, multi-language support and a play through of the interactive interview mini-game with audio commentary by John Passfield, one of the game’s designers.

results.title: Grace Tame visits the Prime Minister
results.brief_description: You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. At her recent visit to Government House, she made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which sent conservatives into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. At her recent visit to Government House, she made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which sent conservatives into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.

Meanwhile, a huge swath of the internet came out in support of Tame’s directness – with stills from the footage shared across social media – likening her demeanour to their feelings towards the Coalition government.

Throughout her tenure as Australian of the Year, Tame has been vocal about the government’s handling of sexual abuse allegations and its treatment of survivors. In April of 2021, when asked about Scott Morrison’s ‘as a father’ response to rape allegations made by Brittany Higgins – which some believe he didn’t take seriously until “viewing it from the lens of being a father of daughters” – Tame responded: “It shouldn’t take children to have a conscience. And actually, on top of that, having children doesn’t guarantee a conscience.” Like this most recent interaction with the Prime Minister, that clip also went viral on the internet, helping solidify Tame’s position as a courageous advocate for sexual assault survivors and a moral champion at a time when many see Australia’s leaders as lacking both courage and morals.

As Imogen Champagne writes in Crikey:, “Conservatives have been trying to silence Grace Tame all year. Now she’s finally given them silence and they can’t shut up about it.”
description_for_label: You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. At her recent visit to Government House, she made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which sent conservatives into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.

results.title: Aussie Ashes win
results.brief_description: After crushing the Brits with a 4-0 sweep in the 2021 Ashes series, the Aussie team celebrated with the customary champagne popping. But not everyone could join in. Skipper Pat Cummins told the players to put down the bottles so Usman Khawaja, who is Muslim and doesn’t drink alcohol, could rejoin. Khawaja killed it in the fourth test, where he made a century in both innings he played. He tweeted the footage, heralding the moment as a step ‘in the right direction’ towards better inclusivity, acknowledging that there’s more work to be done to address racism in Australian sport.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

After crushing the Brits with a 4-0 sweep in the 2021 Ashes series, the Aussie team celebrated with the customary champagne popping. But not everyone could join in. Usman Khawaja was integral throughout the series, particularly in the fourth test when he made a century in both innings, but as a Muslim doesn’t drink alcohol. Skipper Pat Cummins told the players to put down the bottles so that he could rejoin the festivities. Khawaja retweeted the footage, heralding the moment as a step ‘in the right direction’ towards better inclusivity, subtly acknowledging that there’s more work to be done to address racism in Australian sport.

Read Osman Faruqi’s analysis of the moment on they Sydney Morning Herald.
description_for_label: After crushing the Brits with a 4-0 sweep in the 2021 Ashes series, the Aussie team celebrated with the customary champagne popping. But not everyone could join in. Usman Khawaja was integral throughout the series, particularly in the fourth test when he made a century in both innings, but as a Muslim doesn’t drink alcohol. Skipper Pat Cummins told the players to put down the bottles so that he could rejoin the festivities. Khawaja retweeted the footage, heralding the moment as a step ‘in the right direction’ towards better inclusivity, subtly acknowledging that there’s more work to be done to address racism in Australian sport.

results.title: Run for our rights
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @aiww's instagram feed
results.brief_description: Chinese artist Ai Wei Wei is campaigning against threats to journalistic free speech by encouraging others to post videos of themselves “running for our rights”. Australian journalist Julian Assange gave Ai Wei Wei a treadmill he used while living at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London. Assange faces potential extradition and prison in America for publishing US government documents on Wikileaks.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Chinese artist Ai Wei Wei is campaigning against threats to journalistic free speech by encouraging others to post videos of themselves “running for our rights”. Australian journalist Julian Assange gave Ai Wei Wei a treadmill he used while living at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London. Assange faces potential extradition and prison in America for publishing US government documents on Wikileaks.
description_for_label: Chinese artist Ai Wei Wei is campaigning against threats to journalistic free speech by encouraging others to post videos of themselves “running for our rights”. Australian journalist Julian Assange gave Ai Wei Wei a treadmill he used while living at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London. Assange faces potential extradition and prison in America for publishing US government documents on Wikileaks.

results.title: South Dakota "Dash for Cash"
results.brief_description: You’d be forgiven for mistaking this for a scene out of Squid Game, but unfortunately it’s not a hit dystopian TV show – it’s the Sioux Falls Stampede ice hockey team’s inaugural “Dash for Cash”, which saw local teachers compete for money to buy school supplies.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

You’d be forgiven for mistaking this for a scene out of Squid Game, but unfortunately it’s not a dystopian TV show where contestants risk their lives in murderous games for cash prizes – it’s the Sioux Falls Stampede ice hockey team’s inaugural “Dash for Cash”. The people scrambling for $5000 worth of one-dollar bills, while the stadium cheers, are local teachers, who intend to use the money for school supplies. After the footage went viral on social media, it started a seemingly much-needed debate about school funding in America, which saw many teachers reveal that they routinely used their own money to buy classroom necessities, as well as raised questions of how we ended up in a society where desperation is turned into spectacle.

The footage was seen as particularly callous towards South Dakota teachers, who according to CBS News, earn the lowest salary in their profession in America.

“While the Dash for the Cash may have been well-intentioned, it only underscores the fact that educators don’t have the resources necessary to meet the needs of their students,” Loren Paul, president of South Dakota’s teacher union, said in a statement to CBS MoneyWatch. “As a state, we shouldn’t be forcing teachers to wrestle with one another to get the money they need to fund their classrooms.”

At a time when inequality is growing globally and teachers have born the brunt of teaching remotely during the Covid-19 pandemic, more than a few users found the event tasteless at best and at worst, just another sign we’re living in the worst timeline. In response to the backlash, the Sioux Falls Stampede, and CU Mortgage Direct, who fronted the cash, released a statement apologising, saying: “we can see how it appears to be degrading and insulting towards the participating teachers and the teaching profession as a whole.”

The two organisations have since donated a further $15,000 USD to the participants.
description_for_label: You’d be forgiven for mistaking this for a scene out of Squid Game, but unfortunately it’s not a hit dystopian TV show – it’s the Sioux Falls Stampede ice hockey team’s inaugural “Dash for Cash”. The people scrambling for the one-dollar bills (there’s $5000 worth on the ice) while the stadium cheers them on are local teachers, who are going to use the money for school supplies. After the event went viral on social media, it started a debate about funding for schools in America, leading to an additional $500 USD being donated to participants by the event organisers.
